p:
Trying to explain the occurrence of cardiac arrest in 15 patients with SARS, Pan et al suggested some possible mechanisms: (a) lung injury caused by SARS virus leading to hypoxemia and an unsteady state in myocardial electricity; (b) SARS direct causing new myocardial cells and/or conduction system damage; (c) SARS infection aggravating pre‐existing myocardial conditions, or conduction disturbances; and (d) extreme anxiety leading to further endogenous catecholamine release, causing myocardial electrical instability (see Figure 1).
